review.title: Soft Set Based Feature Selection Approach for Lung Cancer Images
review.abstract: Lung cancer is the deadliest type of cancer for both men and women. Feature selection plays a vital role in cancer classification. This paper investigates the feature selection process in Computed Tomographic (CT) lung cancer images using soft set theory. We propose a new soft set based unsupervised feature selection algorithm. Nineteen features are extracted from the segmented lung images using gray level co-occurence matrix (GLCM) and gray level different matrix (GLDM). In this paper, an efficient Unsupervised Soft Set based Quick Reduct (SSUSQR) algorithm is presented. This method is used to select features from the data set and compared with existing rough set based unsupervised feature selection methods. Then K-Means and Self Organizing Map (SOM) clustering algorithms are used to cluster the data. The performance of the feature selection algorithms is evaluated based on performance of clustering techniques. The results show that the proposed method effectively removes redundant features.

metadata.title: Soft Set Based Feature Selection Approach for Lung Cancer Images

sections.heading: 1 INTRODUCTION
sections.text: More people are dying from lung cancer this year than from breast, colon and prostate cancer combined, and early diagnosis of the pathological type of lung cancer could improve the treatment effect of patients. Recently, CT scanning has emerged as one of the key diagnostic tools, thanks to its pattern recognition, machine learning and image processing technology, and feature selection is an essential part of knowledge-gathering, and feature selection is used to improve classification accuracy and reduce the processing time of classification algorithms.

sections.heading: 2 RELATED WORK
sections.text: Amer et al. [6] investigated computed tomography (CT) breast imaging and developed a computer-aided system for distinguishing different lung abnormalities. They investigated texture-based features, Fourier-based features and wave-based features. Aliferis et al. [7] investigates machine learning methods for the development of computer models. These computer models used gene expression data to distinguish between tumor and non-tumor, between metastatic and non-metastatic features, and between histological subtypes of lung cancer. A second goal is to identify small groups of gene predictors and investigate their properties in terms of stability, size and relationship to lung cancer. The idea of attribute reduction and decision-making by means of soft set theory was first used by Maji al. [8] The choice of the attribute is based on the maximum reduction of India and the weighted reduction of Herec-Mail information currently used by the E-Method.

sections.heading: 3 RESEARCH MORTIVATION
sections.text: The proliferation of large data sets in many areas poses unprecedented challenges to data mining [11]. Researchers recognize that feature selection is an indispensable component for successful data mining [12]. In image processing, the feature selection approach takes an enormous amount of time to find a minimum subset of features, and the new research in this area focuses on reducing runtime for the purpose of efficient research. Therefore, this work proposes an effective and efficient approach to finding the reduction quantity.

sections.heading: 5 THE PROCESSING MODEL
sections.text: A typical image processing system generally consists of image acquisition, enhancement, segmentation, feature extraction, feature selection and clustering / classification. The process of lung categorization is shown in Figure 1.

sections.heading: 5.1 Image Enhancement
sections.text: Due to the low quality, the low ability to distinguish abnormalities from their surroundings, and the artifacts, the quality of CT images could deteriorate, sometimes to the point where they become diagnostically unusable. Thus, the first step in pre-processing is image analysis. Therefore, the current step in this work consists in conducting a comparative examination of some image enhancement techniques, namely average filters, Gaussian filters, medium filters [15]. All the filter types mentioned are applied to the noise image. The SNR value is determined on the basis of equation (1) and the SNR values of each image resulting from each filter type are compared, we obtain the most suitable filter that could be applied to the raw CT images [6]. The original image and noise image are shown in Figure 2 and the resulting images from all types of the previous filters are shown in Figure 3. The calculated SNR of each filter image applied to all filters is shown in Figure 1.1.

sections.heading: 5.1.2 Application of Denoising Filters to CT scan
sections.text: The results show that the 5 x 5 median filter offers the highest image quality in comparison to the other filter techniques mentioned above. Thus, it is applied to all raw CT lung images. An example of the filtered CT lung image is shown in Figure 4.

sections.heading: 5.2 Lung Segmentation
sections.text: In this paper, the region Growing Segmentation (RGS) is performed on each image. Figures 5 (a) and (b) show the performance of the before-and-after RGS algorithm and finally, Figure 5 (c) shows the segmented lung image [16].

sections.heading: 5.3 Feature Extraction
sections.text: In this study, we used the grayscale co-occurrence matrix GLCM in four possible directions and the grayscale matrix GLDM to extract texture features from digital CT images. [17] Nineteen texture parameters namely: angular-second moment (f1), contrast (f2), correlation (f3), sum of squares: variance (f4), inverse difference moment (f5), sum average (f6), sum variance (f7), sum entropy (f8), entropy (f9), difference variance (f10), difference entropy (f11), correlation information measurements I (f12), correlation information measurements II (f13), maximum correlation coefficient (f15), cluster shade (f15), prominence (f11), correlation information measurement I (12), information information product (12) and information (17).

sections.heading: 7 EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 7.1. Data Collection
sections.text: The data sets come from the database of the National Cancer Institute and the Mitra Scan Center, Salem. [19] In this experimental analysis, 200 raw CT pulmonary scans are taken. The characteristics table used in this database is in the form of a continuous value with non-categorical attributes. In order to apply the soft-set approach proposed in [9, 13], it is essential to convert the data set into categorical values.

sections.heading: 7.2. Feature Reduction
sections.text: A comparison of the methods USQR, URR and SSUSQR is made on the basis of the subset and cluster performance. The name of the data set is described according to the texture description matrix and the orientation (degree) is used to extract features from the CT lung image. There are 19 different features that are extracted and used in our experiment. The selected features are shown in Table 4. Figure 6 shows the efficiency of feature reduction for our proposed algorithm. It selects the minimum set of features.

sections.heading: 7.3. Performance Analysis of FS algorithms
sections.text: The performance of the uncontrolled feature selection algorithms USQR, URR and SSUSQR are compared before and after the feature selection using cluster and cluster validity measurements; the performance of the cluster validity measurements Dunn's Index and Silhouette Index are presented in Tables 5 and 6. Cluster selection was first performed using the unreduced characteristics, followed by reduced characteristics obtained by dimensionality reduction techniques; Figures 7 (a) and (b) illustrate the performance of the Dunn Index and Silhouette Index using K-means for the data sets selected based on the proposed approach; these figures show the effectiveness of SSUSQR over USQR and URR as it has a higher index value; Figures 7 (c) and (d) show the performance of Dunn Index and Silhouette Index using SOM for the data sets created based on the USR and USR paragraphs.
